I think it's ironic that driving species to extinction is seen as a bad thing except if it's a parasite. We shouldn't do this. There is evidence that parasites play an important role in different ecosystems and that they can actually be beneficial to our health in the long run.

Parasites interact with the immune system. For most of human evolution, parasites have lived inside of us. Because of coevolution, the immune system evolved to actually utilize these immunomodulatory processes of the parasites. There are hints that less parasitic diseases in a region can lead to more autoimmune diseases, allergies, and other immunological disorders.

Like many issues, this one is also not black and white. Parasites are not bad per se.

Controversial hypothesis: The further one is away from the equator the more calories that can be dedicated to the growth of the brain, vs spending those calories on the immune system to deal with parasites. Conversely, the closer to the poles one is, the more one has to expend calories for warmth, depriving a growing brain of much needed fat and calories. So it seems the best place to grow a brain is where it isn't too cold in the winter and not so warm in the summer to allow parasites. Europe, Japan, Korea, the Han Supremacy in China, the Mongols, all from that longitudinal sweet spot. The closer to the equator, the harder it is, and the more crap to deal with, which puts into perspective just how industrious the Indians were. All that heat and nasty parasites and they still made an awesome civilization.

The US government even gives funding to save species internationally with the understanding you cant save everything. There’s a species of parasites that was on the Californian Condor a bird that almost went extinct only a few Californian Condors were left at one point. However that wasn’t known at the time (I think). In doing so the conversationists made that parasitic species extinct. Would they have done anything different if they knew it was harmless and only lived on the backs of the Californian Condor? One has to wonder if the species would still be around today had they had known it was harmless and only found on the backs of the Californian Condor? For sake of not feeling like I left facts out it’s almost certain that both the parasites on the backs of the Californian Condors and the Californian Condors would be extinct had the Californian Condors not been brought into captivity. Diseases like Parkinson's or Alzheimer's get massive amounts of funding because charitable people in the developed world tend to care about the diseases that killed people they knew. The issue with tropical diseases is that the cures might be many times simpler to develop, and consequently the price for one saved life is much lower, however, they do not get the funding because there aren't enough rich people living in these areas (because they would die young from a tropical disease, mostly). It's a vicious circle and we in the developed world need to help if humanity is to reach its full potential.

They just happened to have evolved to feed on us. Sure, they ARE our natural enemies, and I don't mind people killing them - it is only natural for our survival. But they regulate many species, and our species too. If we exterminate them, we break one part of the cycles of nature, and we'll pay for it. Mostly due to overpopulation issues. So, I'm not very impressed - for portraying a struggle in completely unrealistic black and white terms, and for essentially demonizing a whole bunch of creatures that are as much part of this world as we are, are are nowhere as "evil" as they are portrayed here.

There are several problems in this video. We know kurzgesagt has been commissioned by the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation to do such infomercials. This means bias and I would like to explore further some of those bias here.

The drug companies here are painted as doing a humane effort for the benefit of the entire humanity for free. If we were to examine it more closely, we would see that these companies in fact use developing countries as guinea pigs for medical research and people who die from drug related complications are not even publicly reported.

That puts all this humanitarian effort into a different light and all of a sudden what seemed humane, starts to look something else.

The next problem is the unrecognized effects eliminating these ntd's may have in the ecosystem, where everything is in an equilibrium that has established itself during millions of years. We may see uncontrollable population explosion in developing countries. New and more severe disease outbreaks and so on. Bigger migration crises and social unrest on a global scale. Famines. You name it. There is another side to every coin and making a video like this that examines only the other side, you have a problem of severe bias that resembles marketing or brainwashing.

If anyone's interested in what exactly goes on with Dracunculiasis, aka 'Guinea Worm Disease':

1. Seeking relief from pain, sufferer soaks a blister with exposed worm in nearby water source. On contact with water, the worm bursts, releasing hundreds of thousands of immature first-stage larvae into the water.

2. Tiny water fleas ingest the larvae which molt twice, becoming mature third-stage larvae. The process takes about 2 weeks.

3. Another person drinks the water containing the water fleas with the infective larvae. The water fleas are digested, releasing the larvae in the stomach.

4. The larvae, which resist digestion, migrate to the small intestine and penetrate the intestinal wall into the body cavity, where they grow into worms and mate.

5. Fertilized female worms, up to 3 feet long, move through connective tissue to various areas of the body, usually the lower limbs.

6. Approximately a year later, after the larvae were ingested, the worm forms a painful blister near the skin surface. The blister bursts, exposing the worm.

7. The cycle continues...

I've noticed that a lot of videos on this channel blow up an issue by making it appear to be potentially harmful to the viewer. A rendering of an NTD is shown stealing food from a child in a stroller, attacking a woman in a dress and infecting a middle-class looking man drinking water out of a glass. A map of earth is also shown, colored red with little infectious looking squiggly lines flailing about. All of these images make the problem of NTS seem like a widespread on a global scale and potentially hurt the viewer him/herself. This isn't really the case. The vast majority of NTDs don't effect people living in 1st world countries (the primary audience for this video).

This isn't to say we shouldn't care or actively try to stop these horrible diseases from attacking the less fortunate; however, I think it is deceitful make these parasites seem relevant to people living in wealthy countries. By the end of the video, it is explained that NTDs are mostly a problem for small, poor countries, but an uninformed viewer would never guess that by watching the first 3/4 of the story.

The battle you reffered to in the beginning, is know as the Battle of Belasica, or the Battle of Kleidion, and it was fought at the Mt.Belasica in Macedonia between the armies of Byzantine and Macedonia, to be more specific the army of the Macedonian car Samuil. It's not Bulgaria. The mountain is in modern day Macedonia, and even back then it was in the borders of the country.
Another thing, every 100th soldier was left with one eye so they could lead the rest of the army back to the capital. When the MACEDONIAN car Samuil saw what the byzantine had done to them, he suffered a heart attack and died.

Hey, Kurzgesagt, could you plug the END Fund on the end of this video, they'd really appreciate it. The END Fund is an organization that is currently working on eliminating all of or most of the effects of NTDs within African countries and India, and so far they have been a huge success in Burundi and Rwanda. NTDs are mostly not talked about here in the west so I was glad to see this video posted. I think that it is very important to spread the word about this, as NTDs have a much larger impact than Ebola, AIDS, Malaria etc. but is rarely fundraised for or talked about. Feel free to contact me if you would like to know more about the END Fund, and I could put you in contact with them if you would like to learn more about them / help them in any way.

I don't recall hearing the term NTD like this before, but I did know of Dracunculiasis previously. A worm-like parasite one gets by drinking water with a tiny crustacean infected with said worm's larvae. The larvae burrow through the stomach and such, eventually matures, and then pierces itself out from the lower leg or foot. To remove the worm, it's normally attached to a small stick and twisted in order to pull it out. Not only does it take ages to finish, but I believe it causes an incredible amount of pain.
Their eradication can only be good.

Poor - you don't even properly explain what "NTD" means? I've worked in international development - NTD means "neglected tropical disease", referring to the lesser known diseases like compared HIV or malaria. Unlike the title they aren't all parasites, since NTDs include viral and bacterial infections. Also "dracunculiasis" is more commonly known as Guineau Worm, the medical name is rarely used in health prevention so I don't know why you used it here other than to sound fancy.
